newsitem.title: USA: Apple shares continue to rise on Microsoft deal.
newsitem.headline: Apple shares continue to rise on Microsoft deal.

text.p: Shares of Apple Computer Inc. continued to soar Thursday, reaching the highest level in 18 months amid optimism that the $150 million investment from Microsoft Corp. and a new board of directors will bolster the fortunes of the computer maker.

Apple stock was up $3, or 11 percent, at $29.313 in midday trading on Nasdaq. Earlier, the stock traded as high as $30, the highest since March 1996. In the past month, the stock has more than doubled from $13.
Trading was brisk with volume of 24.5 million shares.
On Wednesday Microsoft agreed to invest $150 million in one-time mortal enemy Apple, promised to continue to write business software for the Macintosh and agreed to share its technology with Apple.

Apple also revealed that it had revamped its board of directors. It named four computer industry heavyweights, including Oracle Corp. Chairman Larry Ellison, Intuit Inc. President Bill Campell, Apple co-founder Steve Jobs and former International Business Machines Corp. finance chief Jerome York.

"Can you think of better news? This is very good for Apple," said Daniel Kunstler, analyst at JP Morgan Securities in San Francisco. Kunstler Thursday lifted Apple's stock rating to "long-term buy" from "market performer."
Added David Wu, analyst at ABN AMRO Chicago Corp.: "Yesterday, I would have said Apple doesn't have a future. Today I say it does."

The new board members bring lots of financial and marketing experience, something shareholders had criticised the previous board for not having, analysts said. The new all-star board also could make it easier for Apple to find a new chief executive.
The Cupertino, Calif., company has been without a CEO and chairman since Gilbert Amelio was ousted a month ago.
